items.description: North Sea coast at Withernsea, Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Overtopping waves and spray are expected as a result of high spring tides on Thursday evening (21/10/2021) and Friday morning (22/10/21). Areas most at risk are Southfield Farm between 19:15 and 20:30 on Thursday evening and 07:30 and 07:45 on Friday morning and Spurn Road between 19:00 and 21:00 on Thursday evening and again between 07:15 and 08:15 on Friday morning. Strong winds may also generate windblown spray affecting low lying land near the coast. Please be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Friday morning by 11am, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Cam in Cambridgeshire
items.message:
River levels are rising at the Stapleford river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is possible today, 21/10/2021. We expect flooding to affect the River Cam from Stapleford to Waterbeach.   
With little rainfall forecast for the rest of the day, we expect river levels to begin falling later on today, 21/10/2021.
We are closely monitoring the situation. 
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated by 19:00 on 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely today, Thursday 21 October 2021. River levels are currently high. Areas most at risk are low lying land and riverside areas around Great Yeldham, Castle Hedingham, Sible Hedingham, Halstead, White Colne, Chappel, Fordstreet, and the Toppesfield Brook, and in Colchester between the A12 and East Street. The forecast is for light rainfall during the day and into this evening. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 22 October 2021.

items.description: Humber estuary from Spurn Point to Winestead Outfall

The areas most at risk are low lying land and roads around Kilnsea Village, however strong winds may generate wave and windblown spray affecting exposed coastal areas and roads between these times. Please be careful along exposed footpaths and roads as waves and overtopping spray could be dangerous. This message will be updated on Friday morning by 11am, or as the situation changes.

items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:30am and 02:30am overnight tonight, into Friday 22 October 2021.  Tide levels will be high at Battlesbridge, and Hullbridge riversides. Creeksea Ferry Road onto Wallasea Island may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 2.92 mAODN at 1:30am, on Friday 22 October, which is 0.40m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).  Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 22 October 2021.

items.description: The Essex coast from Clacton to and including, St Peters Flat and the Colne and Blackwater estuaries
items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 12:15 and 14:15 on Thursday 21st October. Clacton Promenade, Lee-over-Sands and Brightlingsea sea front may see some wave overtopping and spray. The Strood at Mersea Island, Coast Road and car parks on the front at West Mersea, and the Hythe and Promenade at Maldon may be flooded. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Clacton of 3.15m AODN at 13:15, on Thursday 21st October, which is 0.71m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We expect that this message will be re-issued for the tide following this, which is over Thursday night and early Friday morning. We will update this message by 6pm today, Thursday 21st October.

Further showers are forecast today and tomorrow is forecast to be dry. River levels have peaked overnight and are now falling in the Lower Stratton area with no further rise forecasted.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area clearing weed/trash screens. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and refer to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. 
This message will be updated this evening, 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: South Somerset Rivers, Upper Reaches
items.message:
The river levels at Donyatt and Ashford Mill have now fallen to normal winter levels. The river levels at Chiselborough have peaked and are beginning to fall slowly following the heavy rainfall over night, but still remain above the Flood Alert threshold. Consequently, the risk of flooding of roads and farmland continues during Thursday, 21/10/21. There is a possibility of flooding for roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges. 
Minimal rainfall is now forecast over the next 24 hours. We will continue to closely monitor the situation. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures and see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: Western Rother
items.message: The Western Rother is still high, following Wednesday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads, gardens and isolated properties along the Western Rother. At Lodsbridge near Selham and Fittleworth river levels will continue to rise through most of Thursday, peaking at about 19:00 21/10/2021 at Lodsbridge and the early hours of Friday in Fittleworth. Flood water could peak very close to properties in both of these communities. Conditions will now slowly improve through Liss, Sheet, Iping and on the River Lod, where in all locations river levels have already peaked or will soon peak. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river a chance to stabilise by Friday, however a return to more normal flows is not expected until next week. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.message: The water level in the Gurnard Luck is higher than normal following heavy rainfall yesterday (Wednesday 20/10/21) when more than half a month’s rain (55mm) was recorded in Cowes. High tide at Cowes is forecast in the early hours of Friday morning at 00:27 on 22/10/21. For 1.5 hours either side of high water, the river will remain a little elevated, but overall the situation will improve and garden flooding in Marsh Road is not expected. Over the next few days, the weather is forecast to remain dry and tide levels are also reducing. No further impacts are currently expected.

items.description: Cripsey Brook in Epping Forest District Council
items.message:
The Cripsey Brook has overnight in response to heavy rain overnight and is expected to be out of banks and flood low lying areas on Thursday 21 October. 
We expect river levels to remain high throughout the day flooding low lying land, roads and gardens close to the river around Moreton and Chipping Ongar. 
Flooding from surface water, where water gathers and flows off road surfaces, could also occur and cause issues during the Thursday morning rush hour. 
No flooding to properties is currently expected.
Avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and follow any local diversion routes.
We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff on standby to attend to any blockages in the river.
This message will be updated this afternoon or earlier if the situation changes.

items.description: Eastern Yar
items.message: The water level in the Eastern Yar remains very high and continues to rise. Yesterday (20/10/21) 55mm of rain was recorded at Knighton. Currently, the river is near the top of the bank in Alverstone. Field flooding is expected along the Yar Valley. Golf Links Road will be flooded and today (21/10/21) minor impact flooding will affect Moreton Common Road. Land around holiday parks in Sandown may flood, as water will struggle to drain to the river. Over the next few days, the weather will be settled and dry. In Alverstone, the river should stabilise around 10:00 this morning (20/10/21), remaining high for several hours, it is unlikely to begin to lower until this afternoon. During this time, it may cause some minor impact flooding to gardens. In Sandown, the river will continue to rise until the early hours of Friday morning (22/10/21). As it peaks, it may be bank full at Sandown Road Bridge. We continue to monitor the forecast. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Friday 22/10/21.

items.description: The Rivers Wid and Can
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to low lying land, roads and riverside areas is likely. River levels are currently high, but are expected to start to drop back down to more normal levels later today. Areas most at risk are low lying roads and riverside areas, including Lordship Lane and Cow Watering Lane around Writtle College. The forecast is for light rainfall during the day and into this evening. Take care on riverside footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate. We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 22nd October.

items.description: Rivers Eden and Eden Brook
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall last night but are beginning to fall. The risk of flooding of roads and low lying land remains high for today, 21/10/2021. Flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. No further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 22/10/2021. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and are actively monitoring the situation. Please avoid walking in or driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is still high, following Wednesday's heavy rain. Near Ardingly the river is now beginning to fall, but towards Barcombe river levels are still rising. Flood impacts will continue to affect a small number of properties near Lindfield Bridge on the B2028, as well as fields, rural roads and gardens all along the River Ouse. Including roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge and isolated properties near Freshfield Mill Farm on Sloop Lane, and the Anchor Inn at Barcombe Mills. The river at Barcombe is unlikely to peak until late afternoon Thursday. Barcombe Mills Road will be affected by flood water. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will enable the river to stabilise through Thursday, and should return to more normal flows by the weekend. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.description: Upper Arun
items.message: The River Arun is still high and rising in places following Wednesday's heavy rain. The Arun is now falling in Horsham, but minor flooding will continue to affect grassy areas and gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court and possibly fields behind Arunside and playground of Arunside School. River levels closer to Pulborough are likely to keep slowly rising until approximately 16:00 21/10/2021. As a result, flood water will be very close to isolated riverside properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Lock. Some water could also affect the A272 Newbridge road near Billingshurst. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river a chance to stabilise by Friday, however a return to more normal flows is not expected until next week. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding through Horsham. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.description: The tidal Deben estuary
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely  between 12:30am and 02:30am overnight tonight, and into Friday 22 October 2021.  Tide levels will be high around the boat yard in Felixstowe Ferry hamlet at the end of Ferry Road, and along riverside areas in Woodbridge and Waldringfield, as well as in surrounding marshland. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 2.73mAODN at 1:30am, on Friday 22 October, which is 0.66m above tide tables, wind Force 5, Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables).    Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are monitoring the situation and do not expect the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 9am tomorrow, Friday 22 October 2021.

The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Southend of 3.85 mAODN at 13:45pm, on Thursday 21st October, which is 0.94m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly. (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more info refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation and will update this message by 6pm today, Thursday 21st October.

items.description: River Blackwater
items.message: The water level in the River Blackwater remains high, but it is now slowly falling. In the last 48 hours, close to half a month’s rain (43mm) was recorded in Romsey. For the rest of the day, the river will remain very high around the mill building and water will be ponded on low lying roads, land and fields, especially at West Wellow. Over the next few days, the weather is forecast to remain dry. It will take another 8 hours before the water level reduces significantly, and it will be several days before the river returns to normal. Given the more settled outlook, no further impacts are currently expected.

items.description: Middle Stour and tributaries
items.message:
River levels remain high at the Hammoon river gauge on the River Stour from the rainfall overnight.  Low lying land and the tributaries between Sturminster Newton and Wimborne will continue to be affected.  

No further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours, 

River levels are remaining high on the Middle Dorset Stour due to overnight heavy rainfall.

We will continue to monitor the forecast and update this alert if necessary.  Consider activating any property flood protection products you may have.  Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.  This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 22/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife is still high, following Wednesday's rain. Minor flood impacts will likely continue to affect fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, and possibly land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre and Rowan Park Caravan Park. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will give the river a chance to stabilise. From 20:00 21/10/2021 the river should begin to fall through Shripney, Bersted and Aldingbourne. The lowering of water levels will be slow and the Aldingbourne Rife will be higher than normal until next week. River levels through Barnham are falling a lot quicker, and are expected to be near normal by Thursday evening. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. Our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk, and we will keep grilles clear through Barnham, including at the Trading Post. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.description: Combe Haven
items.message: The Combe Haven is still high, following Wednesday's heavy rain. However, river levels in Crowhurst are now slowly falling. Minor flood impacts are likely to continue in Crowhurst through Thursday, affecting fields, rural roads and gardens of properties near the Recreation Ground and also near Springfields. Flood water is also likely to be affecting the Bexhill Road Recreation Ground in Bulverhythe. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river a chance to stabilise by Friday, however a return to more normal flows is not expected until next week, particularly in Bulverhythe. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message when the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

items.description: Middle River Medway
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall last night but are beginning to fall. The risk of flooding of roads and low lying land remains high for today, 21/10/2021. Flooding is expected to continue to affect Tonbridge playing fields, town centre car parks and low lying land and roads from Tonbridge through Tudeley and East Peckham. This is likely to include the sports pitches, also known as the racecourse, and Postern Lane in Tonbridge. Flooding of properties is not expected. No further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 22/10/2021. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and are actively monitoring the situation. Please avoid walking in or driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lox

Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, rural roads and gardens along the length of the River Lox. Near Drungeick river levels will continue to rise until approximately 17:00 21/10/2021. By which time, flood water could be very close to properties near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and at the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river a chance to stabilise by Friday, however a return to more normal flows is not expected until next week. Please continue to operate private water control structures to reduce the risk of flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

River levels have now fallen below the level expected to cause flooding.  There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.  No further rainfall is forecast for today, 21/10/21.  
We continue to monitor the situation. Please remain aware of your local situation.

items.description: River Uck
items.message: Minor flood impacts are still likely to be visible along the River Uck following Wednesday's heavy rain. Standing water will remain in fields, gardens and on rural roads throughout Thursday. However, river levels in Buxted, Uckfield and Isfield are slowly falling and so flood impacts should reduce. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will allow the river to largely return to normal by Friday 22/10/2021. Please keep flood protection products in place while residual flood impacts remain. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message when the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

items.description: Rivers Tillingham and Brede
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall last night. The risk of flooding of roads and low lying land remains high for today, 21/10/2021. Flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying land and roads along the River Brede, particularly around Winchelsea and also low lying land and roads along the River Tillingham between Broad Oak and Rye. No further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 22/10/2021. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and are actively monitoring the situation. Please avoid walking in or driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Rother and its tributaries from Turks Bridge to the Royal Military Canal
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall last night but are beginning to fall. The risk of flooding of roads and low lying land remains high for today, 21/10/2021. Flooding is expected to continue to affect low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly in the Crowhurst Bridge area and around Shrub Lane, and also low lying land and roads along the River Rother, particularly around Robertsbridge. No further rainfall is forecast over the next few days. We expect river levels to remain high until tomorrow morning, 22/10/2021. Our incident response staff are out on the ground checking and clearing any blockages and debris from rivers and are actively monitoring the situation. Please avoid walking in or driving through floodwater. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 22/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: North Sea coast at Easington and Kilnsea
items.message: Tides remain high and we are continuing to monitor the situation. We will reissue this warning if necessary

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: The Bull River through Hellingly is still very high following Wednesday's heavy rain, but is now slowly falling. Flood impacts affecting fields, gardens, roads and being very close to a small number of properties will continue on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road Hellingly. The Cuckmere River along Mill Lane, has already fallen considerably from its peak. The river through Alfriston will continue rising during Thursday. Water will be in the fields, and minor flood impacts could also affect North Street, Willows Car Park, River Lane, The Old Clergy House and Deans Place Hotel, Alfriston. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will enable the river to begin to fall by 17:00 21/10/2021 in Alfriston, but river levels are likely to stay higher than normal until next week. Please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.description: River Ingrebourne at Harold Park and Hornchurch
items.message:
Following heavy rain overnight, river levels on the Ingrebourne peaked at Harold park overnight and came out of banks but have since fallen back to within normal levels.
River levels at Gaynes Park are rising slowly but are not expected to come out of banks.
The risk of flooding from the River Ingrebourne has now reduced and levels have fallen below levels of concern. 
No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days

items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain.
No further property flooding is expected.
The forecast is for no further rainfall for today and tomorrow.
River levels have been falling steadily at the Uplyme The Glebelands gauge.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.
Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.
If you have been evacuated only return to your property once the emergency services have advised that it is safe to do so.

items.message:
River levels have risen overnight at the Bruton Dam river gauge as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, 21/10/21.  We expect flooding to affect the B3151 Glastonbury to Meare Road.  Overtopping is forecast from the Glastonbury Millstream and the River Brue at North Drain and Westhay. 
Dry weather is forecast today, 21/10/2021, and we expect river levels to stabilise and begin to decrease. 
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Friday, 22/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: St Johns, Ryde
items.message: The water level in the Monktonmead Brook at St John’s Station remains high, but it is now slowly falling. Yesterday (Wednesday 20/10/21) 60mm of rain fell in Ryde, which is a significant amount. It will take another 6 to 8 hours before the water level in the river returns to normal, some residual flood impacts may remain until then. Over the next few days, the weather should remain fairly dry. As a result, no further impacts are currently expected.

items.description: River Nadder and tributaries
items.message:
River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Nadder due to the overnight heavy rainfall.
Areas most at risk include the River Nadder and tributaries between Donhead St Mary and Salisbury.
No further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours.
River levels are remaining high, but the risk of flooding to low-lying land remains.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 22/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Parrett (upper) from South Perrott to Thorney
items.message:
The level in the River Parrett at the Chiselborough river gauge has peaked earlier this morning following the heavy rainfall overnight and is now falling slowly. This flood warning will remain in force during Thursday due to the high river level. The risk of flooding remains possible for the River Parrett downstream of Gawbridge, the A356 at Chiselborough, the Norton Sub Hamdon to Stratton road and Parrett Works near Martock. 
The heavy rainfall has now passed out of the area and minimal rain is forecast for the next few days. We will continue to monitor the situation and our incident response staff are clearing weed screens. Please keep any property flood resilience equipment in place and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers which may be flooded and refer to local authority website for local road closures. This message will be updated by 10:00 on Friday, 22/10/21, or as the situation changes.

The forecast is dry for the next 24 hours.
River levels will start to fall, but the risk of flooding to roads remains.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.

Plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 22/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Frome from Maiden Newton to Dorchester
Hellingly and Horsebridge
items.message: The Bull River is still very high following Wednesday's heavy rain, but is now slowly falling. Flood impacts affecting fields, gardens, roads and being very close to a small number of properties will continue on Station Road, Church Lane and Church Road Hellingly. The Cuckmere River along Mill Lane Hellingly, has already fallen considerably from its peak, which should help flood impacts ease. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will enable the river to continue to fall through Thursday. Impacts should begin to ease from late Thursday afternoon, and should return to more normal flows by Friday afternoon. Some roads are likely to be affected by flood water, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.description: Lindfield Bridge
items.message: The River Ouse is high at Lindfield Bridge, following Wednesday's heavy rain. However, water levels are now slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect properties at Bridge Cottage and Dean's Water Mill at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield, as well as fields, rural roads, gardens. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday, which will enable the river to continue to slowly fall, and associated flood impacts to ease, through Thursday, and should return to more normal flows by Friday. Please keep flood protection products in place, if you have them, while residual flood impacts remain. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.message: The River Ouse is high following Wednesday's wet weather, when more than half a month's rain (55mm) was recorded at Ardingly. Tide levels at Newhaven on Friday are predicted to peak almost 20cm lower than Thursday. Which means water levels along the lower Ouse on Thursday evening, and on Friday, should not exceed heights we have recently seen. Minor flood impacts could still affect fields, rural roads, and gardens in Hamsey, the Malling Deanery and Pells areas of Lewes and near Piddinghoe Church. Impacts will reduce over the next few days. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday and Monday. Flood risk is not expected to return until another spell of persistently wet weather occurs. Please continue to plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will reissue this message when the risk of flooding to properties increases again.

items.description: Cranleigh Waters near Cranleigh and Shamley Green
items.message: Property flooding is possible. River levels have risen on the Cranleigh Water as a result of a period of sustained rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected today (21/10/21) and flooding of properties is possible, especially Cranleigh and Shamley Green. The forecast is for a dry day today and tomorrow, so levels are expected to fall slowly throughout today and tomorrow. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Activate any property flood protection products you may have, such as flood barriers and air brick covers. This message will be updated this evening 21/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Tillingbourne
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels have risen on the Tillingbourne as a result of heavy rainfall overnight. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected late morning 21/10/21, especially in the Shalford area. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point.
No further rainfall is forecast for today and tomorrow. We expect river levels to rise quickly this morning and fall steadily this afternoon.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area checking trash screens and clearing leaf fall.

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.502 m and is stable and should start decreasing by 09:00 today, 21/10/21. 
There is a risk of water overtopping Haymoor flood storage area and affecting Curload and Stan Moor if this level reaches 8.30 m.
Pumping is taking place at Saltmoor and Northmoor pumping stations. 
Dry weather is forecast for today, 21/10/2021.
The River Tone at Currymoor is forecast to remain stable. 
The River Parrett at Langport Westover pumping station is forecast to remain stable. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated 18:00 on Thursday, 21/10/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Barcombe Mills
items.message: The River Ouse is high and rising. Over half a month's rain (55mm) was recorded at Ardingly during Wednesday. From 10:00 21/10/2021 the Anchor Inn is expected to flood. Flood water will be extensive through fields, and Barcombe Mills Road and Anchor Lane are likely to be covered by water, and potentially impassable. At this stage, internal property flooding at Barcombe Mills is thought less likely. Very little rain is forecast until Sunday. The river should begin to fall by 18:00 21/10/2021, but will not return to normal flows until the weekend. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. Flood protection products are recommended to be installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 22:00 21/10/2021

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: This message has been issued because some minor flooding to riverside roads and footpaths is likely from lunchtime today, Thursday 21 October, and for at least the next 24hrs. High water levels may last for a few days, until the high tides at Great Yarmouth have passed. This is due to a natural tide locking effect. High tidal water moving up the rivers from Great Yarmouth, is currently restricting the normal drainage out to sea at low tide, of the Broads river system. We expect to see high water levels around Potter Heigham, Wroxham boat yards and Ferry road in Horning.  We are not currently expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. Be ready to take action to protect your property if flooding is expected. We are monitoring the situation and not expecting the situation to escalate.  We will update this message by 9am, Friday 22 October 2021

items.message: This message has been issued because some flooding to coastal roads and footpaths is likely between 11:00 and 15:00 on Thursday 21st October. The detailed forecast for those that use it is for a peak level at Harwich of 3.05mAODN at 13:00, on Thursday 21st October, which is 0.97m above tide tables, wind Force 5, North Westerly (mAODN is height above average sea level, for more information refer to local tide tables). Take care on coastal roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We are closely monitoring the situation. We expect that this message will be re-issued for the tide following this, which is over Thursday night and early Friday morning. We will update this message by 6pm today, Thursday 21st October.

items.description: Hoe Stream
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are rising on the Hoe Stream as a result of heavy rainfall. Therefore, flooding of roads and farmland is expected later this morning and into the afternoon 21/10/21. 
No further rainfall is forecast for today and tomorrow. We expect river levels to rise until this evening then to fall steadily overnight and tomorrow.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are in the area checking defences. 
Please remain safe and aware of your local surroundings and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. 
This message will be updated later this evening or if the situation changes.

items.description: Danes Stream
items.message: The water level in the Danes Stream remains very high. In the last 24 hours, more than half a month’s rain (50 mm) has been recorded at Stem Lane. Milford Dam has operated correctly to reduce the amount of water flowing to Milford on Sea. However, the water level in the village is very high and some footpath flooding is occurring. Gardens at Milford on Sea High Street, may also be affected. It is currently high tide at Lymington, which will act to reduce the river’s capacity to drain to the sea until at least 14:00 this afternoon (21/10/21). Over the next few days, the weather will remain dry. Following high tide this afternoon, the level in the river should reduce, and no further impacts are expected. We continue to monitor the forecast. We have checked Milford Dam is operating. Until later on this afternoon, please keep away from the riverside footpaths in Milford on Sea, especially at Milford Bridge, opposite Lucerne Road. If footpaths are flooded, it will be difficult to see where the edge of the main river channel is. This message will be removed by 18:00 on 21/10/21.

items.description: Middle Stour from Hammoon to Sturminster Marshall
items.message:
River levels are rising steadily on the Middle Dorset Stour, Lower Dorset Stour due to heavy rainfall overnight.
Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Middle Dorset Stour, Lower Dorset Stour, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Hammoon, Bere Marsh, Stourpaine, Durweston and Lower Blandford St Mary.
Flooding is expected at Hammoon, Bere Marsh, Stourpaine, Durweston and Lower Blandford St Mary from 02:15 PM on 21/10/2021.
No further rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours.
River levels are high and forecast to rise further.
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area.
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this warning if necessary.
Start acting on your flood plan if you have one
Residents are strongly urged to take action now. Remain safe and be aware of your surroundings.
This message will be updated by 11:00 AM on 22/10/2021, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message:
The drain level at Huish Episcopi pumping station is 6.97 m and is rising slowly. 
Flooding will affect the road from Langport to Muchelney if this level exceeds 7.3 m, the road from Muchelney to Long load if this level exceeds 7.86 and the road from Muchelney to Thorney if this level exceeds 7.93 m. Property flooding is possible if this level exceeds 8.35 m.
Pumping is not currently taking place at Huish Episcopi pumping station. Dry weather is forecast over the next 24 hours. The River Yeo at Muchelney is forecast to slowly rise as a result.  
We are closely monitoring the situation.   
This message will be updated by 10:00 on Friday, 21/10/21, or as the situation changes.
